utterances: But, George...
I mean, as a woman, though, the honest fact is there--if we're looking at certain criteria, a lot of men don't meet the criteria anymore.

If you're looking for someone with a particular education level or certain financial level; in some communities, even if you take all that off the table, there are not marriageable men out there that people want to tie themselves down with.
Yes, they want to have children, but they're not...
But we're not suggesting, Yvonne, that these women are that calculating, often.
Well, I don't know that we...
And it's not like they're saying, `Well...'
But, Ed, we're not...
`...you know, I want to have a baby, but this guy isn't really...'
We're not saying otherwise.
We are OK with it.
Certainly there was a point in time when I don't know that that was a great set of circumstances, but you were not encouraged to have children out of wedlock.
That was not something that was socially acceptable.
That taboo is off the table, frankly...
Right.
...for the vast majority of us.
So, to me, I meet somebody; if that's my inclination, we get together.
If I have a child, you know, I have a child and I move on.
It's not--I don't have the same constraint that it might have been 40 years ago about the consequences of that particular action.
And I think that, certainly, we cannot legislate that.
We have to understand that unless we can put marriage in a context that it makes sense emotionally and financially for people, they're not going to do it.
They're not--they're going to continue to have kids, but they're not going to get involved in that long-term commitment scenario.
George, she raises an interesting point...
I agree with Yvonne.
I agree with her, but this is the truth.
...that this stigma is gone.
The stigma is gone, but something else is happening.
And we see this when we go around--when all of us go around to these college campuses and speak.
You look at the college campuses across this country--and this goes directly to what you're saying, Yvonne--and you look in each classroom and you see a disproportionate number of black women.
And the first question is, where are the black men?
So if you're talking about, quote, ""marriageable material,"" as you put it, it's going to get even worse, based on what we see on the college campuses.
And now it's even across the board that--I think of the latest study that across the board there are more, slightly more, women in general...
Yeah.
...who are going to college than the men are.
So what are the different gradations of criticism of Roy Moore?
The private sector has been looking forward to drone guidelines for some time.
And in a media call Sunday, Department of Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx finally outlined a proposal for new rules on commercial drone use.
Foxx said they keep two basic safety issues in mind.
One, keeping unmanned aircraft well clear of other aircraft, and two, mitigating any risks to people and property on the ground.
The rules would apply to drones under 55 pounds.
They couldn't fly more than 100 miles an hour and no higher than 500 feet.
The drones would also be banned at night and near airports.
They'd have to be used by someone with the proper certification and they'd have to stay in that person's line of sight at all times.
Ryan Calo says it's that last rule, the line-of-sight requirement, that could limit something like, say, Amazon's big plans for drone delivery.
If you have a person who has to be within line of sight of that drone, you might as well throw that person on a bicycle and have them ride the package over to you.
Calo is a law professor at the University of Washington who studies drones.
He says even if Amazon doesn't get everything it wants out of these new rules, a lot of other groups will.
Other things like covering breaking news or precision agriculture, which is a huge use, real estate photography - those you will be able to do within the FAA's proposed rules.
The White House also issued new rules on drones today for federal agencies.
They'll have to examine their drone data-collection policies every three years to make sure civil liberties are protected.
And any federal drone use can't violate the First Amendment or discriminate against people based on things like race, religion or gender.
But the White House memo only applies to government drone use, not private use.
Though the current FAA proposal doesn't address privacy concerns for commercial drones, the agency said it will revisit that issue later.
Matthew Bieschke runs the UAS America Fund, which is helping finance more than $2 billion for the commercial drone sector.
Bieschke says the FAA proposal in particular made him happy.
Frankly, they surprised us a little bit.
Bieschke says the new rules were more liberal than he thought they'd be.
For instance, they don't make drone pilots get the same licenses airplane pilots have to get.
But Bieschke did have one complaint.
Our view is still that the timeline just isn't appropriate.
The FAA guidelines are still in the draft stage and have yet to undergo public comment and revision.
So that means it could be a year or two until the rules are finally approved.
Sam Sanders, NPR News.
And when we think about the future of Iraq, one big concern is al-Qaida's growing strength there.
This week, al-Qaida's arm in Iraq launched coordinated attacks on two prisons near Baghdad.
One was the notorious Abu Ghraib Prison.
To break through the prison walls there, the group used a dozen suicide bombers, and they attacked guards with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades.
Al-Qaida has staged spectacular prison breaks in the past.
It's a tried-and-true method of reinforcing their ranks.
Here's NPR's Dina Temple-Raston.
Until this week, al-Qaida's best-known prison break happened seven years ago.
(SOUNDBITE OF NEWS BROADCASTS)
The prisoners in that great escape dug a tunnel under the prison, which surfaced in the women's bathroom in a nearby mosque.
One of the men who got away had been convicted of masterminding the attack on the USS Cole in 2000.
The escapees became the core of a new branch of al-Qaida.
They called it al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula, or AQAP.
The group put an underwear bomber on a U.S.
plane bound for Detroit back in 2009.
It also hid a bomb in a printer cartridge that was supposed to bring down a U.S.
cargo plane.
Both those plots failed, but they put AQAP on the map.
I would put AQI above AQAP now.
AQI, al-Qaida in Iraq, took credit for this week's prison attacks.
And that's Bruce Hoffman, a counterterrorism expert at Georgetown University.
He says al-Qaida's arm in Iraq has been staging a comeback for months.
This is obviously not something done spontaneously or serendipitously.
Hoffman says the latest prison break was exceptionally well-planned.
The stereotype is that terrorists attack, you know, innocent civilians, soft accessible targets.
When you're hitting a prison, you're talking about - at least in theory - one of the most hardened target sets within a country.
And when you could hit two of them simultaneously and successfully, that's very worrisome.
Worrisome not just because of the sophistication of the attacks, but also because the prison breaks provided the group with hundreds of new recruits.
I'm Myriam Benraad.
I'm research fellow in Middle East studies at Science Po Paris Center for International Research and Studies.

Benraad has been writing about Iraqi prisons for nearly a decade, and she says this operation is a little different from what happened in Yemen, because this time, the men who escaped were ordinary recruits.
They're mostly Salafists, some of them known for being former insurgents.
There's no real figure, high-level figure of al-Qaida in the prisons.
But they're going to get lots of foot soldiers.
Yes.
More than 400 prisoners disappeared from the Abu Ghraib prison alone on Sunday night.
And Georgetown's Bruce Hoffman says that the escapees are likely to end up even more loyal to al-Qaida.
And this is part of - I hate to use this term - but it is part of its HR approach, that if we can get you out, we're not going to forget about you.
Hoffman expects the escapees to head to Syria, where al-Qaida has joined forces with local groups.
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News.
For more than a decade, Troutman has been working on community issues with interfaith ministry volunteer and Ferguson native Toni Burrow.
She's called this place home for 64 years.
